Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
I never thought I'd be grateful to see those things.

Fields.MenuText: Be grateful after they're sunk.
But sometimes the shooting is less stressful than the waiting. I get it.
Lieutenant, if you're telling me you've got a death wish, now's not the time to indulge it!

Fields.DialogueText: Point taken, Captain.
Now you sound like my mother, Captain. No offense.
@BATTLE
We're getting an all-clear from the harbormaster in Rostock. They're not sure we saved the Warnemünde lighthouse, but at least the last surviving Morganas are leaving the scene.
They were heading... what, north-northeast? If we can't pursue, we should probably send word to Copenhagen.
It's worth doing, but my money's on them running for the Kalmar Strait. Word is they're looking for real estate in the west Baltic while the Soviets and the Finns are kicking up dust in the east.
Stockholm?
Not too many sightings that far north. Not yet, anyway. Setting aside the ongoing mess in the Gulf of Bothnia.
Do we have any explanation yet about the noise?
I'm not sure "noise" is the right word. It's more like getting kicked in the chest every three seconds.
They're Morgana devices. If anybody knows what they are, they're not telling us - though Yeoman Savary says some of the civilian press is worried that they're trying to trigger earthquakes.
Bet that sells papers.
People I've talked to on the radio say it gets worse the closer to Danzig you go.
Then maybe it's best we came out of the leap where we did. We get a little more time to acclimate.
How much more time, sir? Do we have a plan?
Ask me again when we've got the fires out.
Ja. Yes, sir.
... I've always liked lighthouses. Even before I ever set foot on a boat. Just the idea of buildings that exist solely to keep people from accidentally killing themselves in the dark.
Yeah. Well, maybe we got here in time to save this one.
That'd be nice.
What's going on? Who are we spying on?
I'm not spying. I'm being alert in case I need to call in the MPs.
Da, da. Your problem, Leytenant, is that you think spying is something to be ashamed of. And you call yourself an officer!
Huh.
What?
You called me by my rank. You sick or something?
Just trying to be respectful.
Sure. I repeat - you sick or something?
Mais, Capitaine-
Just give me five seconds, Miss Savary!
Lugin? What's the word?
My contacts say Rostock is in chaos, Kapitan. I can get vegetables, but no luck on cheese or canvas.
Right. I'll take it.
Any interest in a Seeziel-Feuerleitanlage C.33? Slightly used?
What's that?
It's a director. We use them with the guns to-
Explain later.

Fields.MenuText: Lugin, I appreciate the offer, but I'd rather have something we can eat.
Add another favor to my list. Where did you even get this?

Fields.DialogueText: Da. I'll keep looking.
A friend of humanity. He doesn't do names.
Cheerio!
Capitaine, you heard him - chaos!
Let me go there, just for the day, and see what's going on. You need fresh intelligence, n'est-ce pas?
That includes local politics as well as the "POUM POUM POUM" the Morganas are making, surely!
I'm not sending a lone French national into a German riot, Miss Savary.
My German is excellent. I can pass.
Yeah, in my experience, "I can pass" works until it doesn't. And I thought you were out to be a yeoman, not a reporter.
A yeoman is whatever the Captain says it is.
You can talk to anyone coming onboard the ship - new recruits, people from the harbormaster's office, whatever. But you're not disembarking unless you want to be left behind.
The lady of the ship has sensed Morganas incoming. We could be on the move at any-
*ALARM*
- moment.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad we agree.
That's not actually the way the rank system is supposed to work.
Miss Savary, I admire your spirit, but take a breath.

Fields.DialogueText: Does the Neutrality Fleet have a formal rank system yet? That's a serious question, by the way.
I'll look into it. In the meantime-
Well, look at you. Second extended vacation since the shooting started.
It's not a vacation if you can't get a martini.
How're you feeling?
Everything's delightful. Thank you for asking.
I had to get him away from the infirmary or Dr. van Geffen was going to throw him into the ocean.
Pff. She's more mobile, but I've got the muscle mass. I like my chances.
Hai, hai. You're very manly and strong.
... I know you're being sarcastic, but I'll take it.
Is he behaving himself?
Hai! Especially when he's medicated!
Lies. I've been medicated since I first joined up and I haven't once... *ngh* ... behaved myself.
I never doubted it. You look like a man who should be sitting, though.
I'll find a chair!
I hope she's been helpful. I actually told her to look after you as a punishment; I didn't think she'd take to it quite so enthusiastically.
I think "enthusiastic" is her only setting.
So, which one of us were you punishing?

Fields.MenuText: *grins*
Not you. I thought having someone to push around would help the recovery process.
Well, originally her, but a good captain makes the most of opportunities.

Fields.DialogueText: You know, in hindsight I'm finding it harder and harder to understand why the Belle chose you to be captain instead of me.

Fields.MenuText: Greater tolerance for paperwork?
They have strange senses of humor.
I could give you a list.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh.
Anyway, Sayako's doing fine. She's a little bit smug about the globe thing, but she's a good kid.
And I think she's secretly grateful to have an excuse to keep hiding from the French girl.
I thought she might be.
How's the war? Things gone to hell since I stopped coming to the bridge?
Depends. How *are* you feeling?
Tired. Sore. But it could've been worse. My torso got cut up, but nothing too deep. Doesn't seem like any of my pipes have burst.
And the harpy is actually a hell of a field surgeon. I'm going to have some gorgeous scars when this is done.
Don't tell her I said that.
My lips are sealed.
So?
The Soviet Union has invaded Finland, supposedly because the Finns are collaborating with the Morganas.
Are they?
Probably not. The Morganas have been building machines in Finnish waters, but they've built them here too.
I can hear it. Feel it, really.
You and the whole port of Rostock. There's been unrest for days - they've been having supply shortages anyway, and "doomsday weapons" that keep people from sleeping is just making things worse.
Rumors says it's even worse in Danzig.
I don't suppose Hitler's looking at this and rethinking the land war.
Last I heard, the official position is that the Morganas are working hand-in-hand with the Jews. And maybe the Bolsheviks - which I'm sure is news to Stalin.
So what are you going to do about it?
Oh, you know me. It'll probably involve blowing something up.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Kapitän? Do you have a minute for good news?
Say forty-five seconds. Talk fast.
We've just gotten word that the Americans had Constitution's last letter read to the U.S. Senate - and broadcast over the radio.
They're saying there's going to be some kind of vote on expanding support to the League.

Fields.MenuText: She was a hell of a ship.
She should've been able to read that letter herself.
Now we just have to find a way to keep the Soviet-Finnish war from blowing it all up.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja.
Ja.
Preferably by saving Finland.
I'm always impressed by your optimism, Mr. Cassel.
@BATTLE
Captain? We're packing up and leaving port?
We are. You'll get the full brief this afternoon, but apparently a U-boat Belle believes she's pinpointed the location of the Morgana...
Groaning machine?
I was going to say "broadcast device," but sure. Your take is probably more accurate.
It's underwater?
"Semi-submerged" is the description. It's also guarded - our friends couldn't get close enough to deliver a torpedo themselves.
What about bombers?
Have you seen those skies? It's like the weather is taking sides.
Besides, I get the sense that German high command doesn't think emergency bombing raids five nautical miles out from Wustrow send the right message.
Right. Does anybody know what the thing is actually doing? Apart from scaring the hell out of people with weird noises?
No. But there's a broad agreement that the world won't be a worse place if we blow it up.
Hm. I bet Rostock has mixed feelings about seeing us go.

Fields.MenuText: Because we're keeping the mist away?
Because they're telling the rioters we'll bombard the shore if things get out of hand?
Not our concern, Lieutenant.

Fields.DialogueText: But at the same time we've got hundreds of people lined up looking for work onboard. Marie-France says people are shouting about us stealing Rostock's women.
I hadn't heard that one.
I'm exaggerating. Slightly. But we have a reputation for being very effective, and the powers that be want the public to think that we're on the side of the law.
It may not be anything we can affect, Captain, but I don't think there's any harm in being-
*SCREAMING*
She heard this how?
Interviews with new arrivals. And she's borrowing like crazy against her first paycheck to get newspapers sent to-
What's going on?
Midshipman! What's the problem?
There was... there was just one of them to port, Captain!
I don't see a ship.
Not a ship! Just the dark lady, sir! Twenty feet tall and standing on the water!
That's-
Submarine.
Hell.
All hands to action stations! Now!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine!
... This isn't the first time I've found a strange woman waiting in my quarters, but you're the first human one in a while.
I did knock first.

Fields.MenuText: I'll take you at your word.
And when you realized I wasn't here, you broke in. Not the way it's supposed to work, Miss Savary.
I don't care. I just want to sleep.

Fields.DialogueText: Very gracious.
I thought I heard someone moving around. It could've been a spy.
Uh-huh.
I won't take more than a moment of your time, Capitaine.
So. What can I do for you?
I would just like to ask you a question. Non! Two questions.
Is this a personal matter?
Not particularly. But I think one of these questions should be asked privately.
Okay. Shoot.
One: does this ship have a newspaper of its own?
It's... erratically published. But, yes. I think our friendly Belle is the person to talk to if you want to know more.
Formidable. Merci.
Question two?
Wait. Do you need to stand so close?
It's so I can whisper. The walls literally have ears.

Fields.MenuText: Carry on.
The walls know better than to listen to private conversations.
I like my personal space, Miss Savary.

Fields.DialogueText: Bon.
Still, there's no harm in being careful. You don't disagree, Capitaine?
As you wish!

Fields.MenuText: I do disagree.
Not at all.

Fields.DialogueText: So.
What if the Morganas applied enough pressure to Germany to make them consider a negotiated end to the land war and a return to something like the old borders in the East?
I don't think that's what the Morganas are after.
But let's suppose that they might achieve it by accident.
Capitaine, I've talked to the new crew members we gained in America. I'd say most are men - some are adventurers. Some see an opportunity to do their duty to the world.
The people who came looking for positions in Rostock were mostly women. The able-bodied men are already being pressed into service for the war, oui?
But the women - they're seeing their families poisoned by the mists, and they're finding food harder and harder to come by, and they think that perhaps our war is more important than Hitler's.
What if that's a trend - or if it becomes a trend? What if the men also come to prefer to fight the Morganas than the French or the English?
It would make the naval war - and my job - a lot easier, if that's what you're getting at.
And the League's job?
Sure.
So. This is question number two, which I will whisper.
Why aren't you letting the Morganas terrorize the German Baltic?  You can't be everywhere, even with teleportation - so why are you fighting them here instead of somewhere else?

Fields.MenuText: Because I have my orders.
Because a Neutrality Fleet that doesn't protect everyone wouldn't work at all.
Because this is where I want to be.

Fields.DialogueText: Interesting.
Those German women are coming to us because they trust that we're looking out for them, regardless of politics. If we lose that, things don't get easier for the League. It's the opposite.
Interesting.
Is that the answer you were expecting?
I wasn't expecting anything, Capitaine. I'm just trying to understand why a bunch of war goddesses are willing to follow you to the ends of the earth.
*ALARM*
Let me know if you figure it out.
@BATTLE
You think they're towing the thing around, Captain?
I don't know. Maybe it was misdirection all along, and that U-boat just saw what they wanted her to see.
But, yeah, they're probably just towing it. You'd think we'd be able to follow it by the sound, but....
Maybe the sound doesn't just have to come from one place, though? Um... permission to come on the bridge and so on, Kanchou?
"And so on?"
I'm trying, okay? Lieutenant. Kanchou.
Permission granted, and so on. What did you mean?
Well, we can blink from place to place now, right? And there's at least some reason to believe that the Morganas can too.
So what if their widget is, like, producing the vibrations we're hearing and they can push those vibrations out somewhere else?
I'm not saying they are, but... I mean, it's the sort of thing I worry about at three in the morning. What if some day they can just make toxic mist appear in, like, downtown Chicago?

Fields.MenuText: ... Would you be willing to write your concerns down for us?
I don't blame you for worrying, but let's deal with what's right in front of us for now. So to speak.
What if some day *we* can just make bombs appear on Vanity's deck? We're learning these tricks too.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. It's kind of exciting, isn't it?
Fair enough. Kyōshuku de gozaimasu!
Like... formally? Sure, but, if there's a special format or something I don't know what it is.
Just notes. If we end up sending it farther up the food chain, our friendly neighborhood Belle will help you clean them up.
Yatta! While she does, can I ask her questions about how she-
Probably not.
Nuts.
So, Miss Kirishima - are you here for a reason?
Oh. Hai! The doctors are arguing about what kinds of painkillers we should be stocking again - apparently Mr. Lugin can get us all kinds of stuff that Dr. van Geffen thinks he shouldn't.
So they're wondering if you can set up a meeting, or-
I'll just warn you now, Captain. It's totally possible that Lugin's talking about raw opium. That guy...
I get it. Kirishima, tell them-
*ALARM*
It'll wait.
@BATTLE
Ugh. We've lost the radio - nothing but... whispers... on every frequency.
It's not the first time. I appreciate the report, but just stick with the protocol... unless there's more?
Not really. It's a bit more unsettling than usual, because that noise makes them all feel so close, but... well, it's fine.
I'll take it anyway. Go on, Mr. Cassel.
The Americans are apparently expanding their responsibilities under the Zurich Agreement. They're not joining the League yet, if I understand this correctly....
We can be stubborn about that kind of thing.
They're also insisting on language discouraging the British from seizing German goods from neutral vessels. I mean, the language is universal, but everybody knows that's what they mean.

Fields.MenuText: Good.
Hm. That could turn out to be short-sighted.
Interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: Anything that reduces friction between the navies gives *us* more room to operate.
Never mind the land war - as the Morgana mess goes on, I think we're all going to need more flexibility in dealing with smuggling, not less.
I bet German high command is happy.
Not this week, they're not. You haven't seen the complaints I've been getting.
Well, that's something.
We did get some good news before we were cut off, though. Nothing that'll help us right now, but-
But they're ramping up industrial production, and they're passing laws allowing for easier Neutrality Fleet recruiting on American soil.
It's not nothing.
Not the complaints, obviously. I mean...
You can just stop there.
Hm.
Danke. Someone needs to say it, but-
@BATTLE
Somehow, that "someone" is always you.
Taking in the view of Stettin, Yeoman Savary?
Oui. And looking out for Russians bearing newspapers.
Wait. Yeoman? It's official?
Well, Belles are empowered to choose their crews, and it seems clear that Constitution had you acting as her de facto personal clerk. So, yes, we got it through.
Our Belle is hammering out the organizational details now, but you'll effectively be a petty officer - and, with luck, you'll be taking some paperwork off my hands.
Ma plume est votre plume, Capitaine.
I'm very glad to hear it.
So, as a recognized member of your crew, may I ask a question about our current mission?

Fields.MenuText: Of course.
If it pertains to your new duties.
If it would take more than thirty seconds to answer, you might be disappointed.

Fields.DialogueText: How do I know if I don't ask?
I'll take the chance.
Are we still looking for the "semi-submerged" Morgana device? Do we think it's close?
This is preparation. We're mostly here to be briefed on the things - the Germans, the Soviets and the League have all sent experts to help us figure out what they're doing.
Can you tell me if there's a dominant hypothesis? Does anyone think they have these things figured out? Earthquakes? Psychological attacks?
Apparently there's some concern that they're trying to block our new travel systems. If that's the case, everything else is just a byproduct.
But that's a big if. I don't-
Kapitan? Sorry to get between a lioness and her prey-
I should be annoyed, but I like "lioness."
- but I've spoken to someone who has a torpedo to unload. Are we interested?
"A torpedo to unload?"
In an entirely above-board and legitimate way, I'm sure. Give him a couple of hours and he'll have paperwork to prove it.
... What kind of torpedo?
Kamikaze something-or-other. I'm sure it's perfect for destroying Mongol fleets.

Fields.MenuText: Not this time.
Okay. We can always make room for something else that explodes when near a Morgana.

Fields.DialogueText: "Spasibo, Orest Anatolyevich! Excellent work, as always." "Not at all, Kapitan - it's a pleasure to serve!"
You should consider that conversation implied.
Hm. And my newspapers?
Da, da. Your sister was interested, so I left them with her.
Quoi? My what?
I need to go make that call, Kapitan. Do svidanya!
... That is a very strange man.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
"Anatolyevich?" I thought you said your father's name was Ivan.
Ah, who can remember the trivial things?
Yeah? I don't like "prey."
"Spasibo, Orest Anatolyevich! Excellent work, as always." "Not at all, Kapitan - it's a pleasure to serve!"
Seems like the best way to test it is to see if we can teleport out.
Except, even with the globe, our short-range jumping abilities are untested. And if we jump back to Boston Harbor and can't get back....
They're not using these devices all over the world, are they? As far as we know, it's just the Baltic?
Correct. So, if it *is* meant to inhibit our movements, are they trying to keep us from going in, or from getting out?
Is it a barricade or a trap?
Right. Assuming that's what it is at all. All anyone's willing to say for sure is that there seem to be a lot of electromagnetic spikes similar to what they've recorded when we jump.
So it could also be that more Morganas are blipping in and out constantly.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not even sure that that's the worst-case scenario.
We picked ourselves a heck of a war, huh?
It's one hypothesis. We don't have much evidence for any of them yet.

Fields.DialogueText: And all of this is distracting us from what's going on in Finland.
We're the flagship of the Neutrality Fleet, Captain. I think, technically, what's going on in Finland is distracting us from this.

Fields.MenuText: Fair point. One crisis at a time.
I don't think so. I don't think it's a coincidence that this all going down in the Baltic.

Fields.DialogueText: So what do we do?
We redouble our efforts. We capture one of those semi-submersibles if we can-
One of them? Definite confirmation there are more?
Probably at least four between Rostock and the Åland Islands. It's unclear whether there are any in the Gulf of Bothnia - the Morgana presence there is hard to crack.
The plan is to box one in. Coordinate with the Kriegsmarine and the Soviet Baltic Fleet, pin it down, take what we need.
Brace yourself for some barely suppressed outrage from August. Assuming we can get the radios working well enough to communicate with our allies.
I look forward to it, sir.
*ALARM*
Guess it's that time again.
@BATTLE
Almost in range, Captain - but they're not our girls. No sign of the package.
We're a good sixty miles from the last sighting. I'm not surprised.
Hey, we learned to teleport. Sometimes good things happen.
@BATTLE
Heh.
I just want you all to know I haven't missed this place at all.
Doc! Good to see you on your feet!
How's our patient, Seaman Kirishima?
I am a bundle of joy and good will, and I bring delight to everyone I meet.
I would push him overboard, but the Belle would catch him and then you'd make me watch him longer for punishment.
No. He's terrible.
I'm lovely.

Fields.MenuText: This is true.
I would only punish you if you didn't let me watch.
I take it you're on the mend, then?

Fields.DialogueText: So unfair, Kanchou.
I can respect that, actually.
I leave it to the Dutch harpy to report on my condition, Captain.
For the record, he traded my newspapers for booze.
Yes, well - news is transient. A good single malt is forever.
Something to read is forever. I'll be surprised if that whiskey lasts out the week.
Take your heresies elsewhere, Lieutenant! I'm here to make sure our captain didn't die in battle.
Uh-huh. Give me a wrist, Captain. Let's see if that pulse is still where we left it.
Is it true the League is going to kick the Soviet Union out? Over Finland?

Fields.MenuText: I haven't missed this.
I'm at least 60% confident I didn't.
Glad to have you back.
Is that what the newspapers said?
They probably should, but I doubt it.
Unlikely. The League needs all the help it can get against the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: There are some hints.
Huh. I thought "unity against the common foe" was your middle name.
Invading your neighbors isn't exactly unifying. In my perfect world, the threat of kicking the Soviet Union out would make Stalin back down.
And Finland?
Yeah, I really didn't miss your bridge visits at all.
I have to assume that having everyone in the same League makes the odds for a peaceful, just resolution *more* likely, not less.
Hm.
Well, for the record, your heart is still beating.  Pulse is pretty good, actually.
And now I think I'm going to go sit down for a minute.
Doctor? Are you all right?
Mm. It's just sometimes I feel like somebody fished a pound and a half of metal out of my side. Weird, huh?
Excuseer mij-- do you have a minute?
A minute. Not much more. Word from the Belle grapevine is that our target is headed our way fast.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
That's interesting - the radio's been working pretty well today.
Huh.
Well, what do you need, Mr. Cassel?
I've been asked to tell you something off the record and ask if it makes any sense.

Fields.MenuText: Is this a joke?
No.
This should be good.

Fields.DialogueText: It's about Belle behavior, sir. And strangeness.
... Go ahead.
Apparently multiple Belles - British and German - have reported unusual dreams. About Uruguay.
Some kind of battle. And they say the dreams are getting more urgent.
The Belles have been talking about it among themselves, and they don't know what's going on, but they thought you should be made aware of it. Unofficially.
Well, that's-
Damn.
Don't take this the wrong way, Captain, but you look like you ought to be unconscious.
And that Morgana noise has quieted down some since we sank the... thing. You might even be able to sleep if you give it a shot.
I just spent fourteen hours negotiating with the League, the Germans, the Soviets, the French, and I don't know who else. I *want* to be asleep.
Don't think it's going to happen, though.
I take it this is about our sunken Morgana device.
And submarine access. Whose Belles get to poke at it, take notes, and maybe try to recover it.
And the results?
Germans and Soviets share primary access with an American submarine Belle on-site to document and ensure fair play. The Brits and the French can have destroyers in the area to monitor.
You happy with that?

Fields.MenuText: I'm happy it's settled.
Sure. Why not?
I'm just trying to tell myself it could be worse.

Fields.DialogueText: So what's the situation here? Any sign of Morganas coming back to retrieve the device?
I guess I know why you're in charge. That keen insight.
Rampant pessimism, you mean.
To-may-to, to-mah-to.
We've also apparently got write-ups from some of the Belles having Uruguay dreams - Graf Spee most vividly.
I'm not clear to see them until you say I am, but I'll be interested to hear how they compare to the real mess down there.
Looking forward to grappling with the existential questions that might come from Belles seeing the future?
Existential questions, hell. If that's what's going on I'm playing the stock market.
Make sure the Belles don't get there before you. We can't afford another Depression.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitaine? You've heard the latest?
I've been talking to the harbormaster for the last couple of hours. If it isn't about freight access, I haven't heard it.
The Soviets and the Finns are inviting League monitors to the front.
The Soviets claim that this will provide proof that the Morganas are assisting the Finns; the Finns have been promised that Soviet war crimes will be reported.
It's all apparently supposed to lead to some kind of mediation. Do you think it will?
In the sense of the League being in a position to negotiate an end to the fighting there?
Ouais. If you like.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't count on it.
No harm in hoping.
The fighting helps the Morganas more than anyone else. The League needs to do its damnedest.

Fields.DialogueText: Non? Why not?
Not a very forceful statement.
But what can they do, really? Doesn't the League need the Soviets more than the Soviets need the League?

Fields.MenuText: Because we've just spent the last two months redefining the League's mission. It's about fighting the Morganas now, and everything else is secondary.
Because this isn't the sort of war where we can expect to get lucky.
But it's honest.
No, it's not.
That's just because I'm famously stoic.
No. And I hope Stalin understands that.
And there's the problem right there.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if you-
*VWOM*
Capitaine? Is that another Morgana-
*VWOM*
I've heard sailors from the Baltic talk about Morgana lights in the mist, but I didn't know they were so... unearthly.
*THUNDER*
... I'm going to the bridge, and in about three minutes we're going to sound general quarters. You might want to beat the rush.
Oui, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Yeoman Savary. Are you supposed to be here?
I asked her to come up - though that was before we knew we were looking at Morgana company.
It's past time we start taking notes during our conversations about the enemy. I'm sure I've let ideas go by without follow-up because I've been too tired to remember them.
But this isn't the time, Capitaine?
We'll have to cut it short, but- Mr. Cassel, fill the lady in on the latest.
Well, yesterday, at 14:03, there was an "unexplained meteorological incident" visible from about the Gulf of Riga to the Gulf of Danzig. Electrical storms, high-velocity winds, freak hailstorms.
Overnight, Morgana mist-related fatalities in the region spiked about 350% above where they were a week ago.
And people across the region reported seeing "enormous shapes" out in the mist.
On land, ou-?
No, out here.
We've also had a report from the De Ruyter Belle. She's documented advanced repairs and organizational improvement from the Morgana navies in just the last two weeks.
They arrived here broken in September, and suddenly they're fixing themselves in fundamental ways.
I should be writing this down, oui?
In shorthand. And I'll ask you to leave the notes with our Belle when they're not in use - she can secure them until we get a chance to review them.
So, how much do we think this has to do with that noise-maker we sank? Is that included in any of the reports?
The timing is right, but early reports from the investigating subs don't offer a lot of insight into what the thing might actually do. Though the Belle thinks it's probably toxic to humans.

There's another angle to this that we haven't discussed. The Japanese government has officially petitioned the League of Nations to send us to waters near Hokkaido to investigate... I don't know what.
Other disturbing Morgana innovations.
I think the implication is that Japanese willingness to work with the League may depend on the League's willingness to work with them.
There's not a lot of interest in supporting a force that's tied up in the North Atlantic and along European coastlines.
Do we have a choice? I mean, people need us here!
We have some discretion in the missions we accept - but people may need us there, too.
And it would be a chance to observe the Morganas in a different context. See if they really are worse here than everywhere else.
They were bad enough along the American coast.
True.
So you think we should go?

Fields.MenuText: No. But if we're ordered to go, we will.
We can always come back in a hurry if it's a waste of time.
I'm leaning that way, yes.

Fields.DialogueText: But it-
*ALARM*
There they are.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, before we go...
We're not buying untested German pharmaceuticals to resell in Japan. We've had this talk already, Lugin.
Da, da. I have learned to accept what cannot be changed.
I have a lead on a rangekeeper. Apparently it was salvaged from a British ship and the German and British are bickering with the League over who gets to keep it. So why not us?

Fields.MenuText: Excellent. Get me whatever I need to sign.
Don't need it right now. Good find, though.

Fields.DialogueText: A pleasure to be of service.
Is it really?
Let's all pretend.
By the way, your newspapers and hideous perfume are in the usual place.
If that means you gave them to the Japanese girl-
Is that the time already? I should go.
He's like one of those big, ridiculous sheepdogs that brings you muddy sticks it finds in a field and hopes you'll be impressed.
There's always a mess left behind, but it's also kind of adorable.

Fields.MenuText: I have no idea how to respond to that.
I don't think that's a comparison he'd appreciate.
Easy for you to say it's adorable. You don't have to housebreak him.

Fields.DialogueText: You're the capitaine. I think you just have to look stoic and nod.
Oh, that would defeat the whole point.
That... is an image that will haunt me.
So, what can I do for you, Yeoman?
Our Belle asked me to get your signature on some paperwork for the Rostock harbormaster. Preferably before we go to Japan.
Yeah, that would-
*ALARM*
Hold that thought.
@BATTLE
A pleasure to be of service.
Okay, people. With luck, we're in the Sea of Japan.
Lieutenant McPhee, get the navigation team together with our Belle. We need to figure out exactly where we are and where it's safe to go.
Mr. Cassel, get on the radio and see if you can-
*vwom*
Captain. Did you hear-
*vwom*
They're out here too.
*VWOM*
Sound general quarters, get the lookouts in gear, and somebody tell our Belle that her first job is to find the enemy before they find us!
@BATTLE
Right. Keep the lookouts in place. Somebody get Lugin and Kirishima over to the radio room - if Mr. Cassel makes contact with any locals, let's not have to rely on his Russian and Japanese.
Captain, you have a minute for a stupid question?
They're the kind I handle best. Go.
What if the noisemakers are just some kind of alarm system?
I mean, the sound is terrifying if you're up close, but we know it carries for miles. And maybe the electromagnetic activity the scientists detected is a broadcast we haven't learned how to decode.
Maybe the Morganas are just constantly telling one another where we are.
... My gut feeling is that there's more to them than that. The pulse, or whatever you want to call it, seems to be echoing jump anomalies, remember.
But it's a good thought. I think that may be part of it.

Fields.MenuText: And if it is, we need to figure out how to work around it.
And if it is, maybe we can find a way to use it against them.
We really need to prioritize trashing these things.

Fields.DialogueText: For now, though - navigators and our Belle. Figure out where we are, Lieutenant.
Yes, sir!
What?
It's Stalin's birthday today.
Ey.
I'm trying to listen to the radio here. For signs of contact. From anybody.
Do you think he's having a party?
Oh, da. I understand birthday parties are a very big deal in the upper reaches of the Party.
Big cake shaped like Karl Marx's beard?
Ahem.
Oh, Kanchou! *awkward salute*
At ease. Mr. Cassel, any progress?
We've had sporadic contact with Japanese vessels, sir. Miss Kirishima has been incredibly helpful there.
Aw.
I don't know if Enoch - I mean, Lieutenant McPhee - passed it along, but we're only a couple of hours away from....
Pardonnez-moi. Just here to take notes.
I don't mean to interrupt.
Miss Kirishima?
Brain. Frozen.

Fields.MenuText: Please get over it.
That hasn't stopped you from talking before.
We'll just all stand around awkwardly, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Gomen! Gomen! Yeah, we're-
*ALARM*
Yatta!
@BATTLE
And that's the situation. The Morganas appear to be extremely active around the Kuril Islands, and the Soviets are concerned that they're trying to incite new hostilities between the USSR and Japan.
We're here on behalf of the League to investigate Morgana activity, facilitate goodwill and fellowship between the local great powers, and document whatever needs documenting.
I don't know if our points of contact have anything to add...?
Um... I don't think the Japanese people on the radio were really comfortable talking to me. Because I'm... not actually very Japanese anymore, it turns out. And I'm a woman in a man's job.
But they were super-worried about what's going on further south. Like, they think the Morganas are helping the Chinese down along the border with French Indochina, and we should be helping there.
Oh, ja. Let's help out in a land war of conquest!
I'm not saying we should! It's just... they may ask us to at some point to prove that the League is on Japan's side. I don't know, that's just the feeling I get.
Have we received any orders along those lines, Capitaine?
No. Again, we investigate in the north and we facilitate communication between the Soviets and the Japanese. That's our brief.
And if that brief changes?

Fields.MenuText: We'll deal with that if it happens.
We find the most effective way to follow our orders.
Then I will have a series of interesting and respectful conversations with my superior officers.

Fields.DialogueText: Our Soviet friends had a few words about what's going on in Finland as well, if anyone's interested.
I think they were very forthcoming. Because they think I'm an admiral.
Oh, for God's sake.
I never *said* I was an admiral! I can't be held responsible for any staged background chatter they may have overheard!
I still can't believe the Neutrality Fleet is paying you for this kind of thing.
I know. It's an amazing new world!
What are our Soviet contacts saying?
The Finns are putting up a fight. The Red Army doesn't have its best toys in the right places. Much wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Excellent! Do you think the League might actually be able to talk them into withdrawing?
... Probably not. Nyet.
We'll deal with that when and if we return to the Baltic. But land conflicts aren't our primary concern. We just need to get used to that.
*ALARM*
On that note...
@BATTLE
Hey. So... you know who I am, right? And about... everything?
Oui - Orest told me. Though, even before that, the fact that you kept diving into lifeboats when you saw me coming was something of a red flag.
...I still need to study the flag code...
Can I help you with something?
No! No, I just thought... I mean, if there were any questions you wanted to ask me about Bertie - I mean, your father....
I mean, he was a private man, and it's not like I could tell you much, but-
You couldn't tell me anything.
Well, I mean, I *could*. He basically took me in after my parents and I... um... went our separate ways.
*sigh*
I don't mean to be cruel, but you do understand who Albert Granville was, don't you?
I don't follow.
He was in intelligence, mademoiselle. His whole professional life.
Do you really think he "took in" a brilliant but emotionally vulnerable industrial spy with family connections to Tokyo military elements because he was sentimental?
And that woman who says she's his wife - you know the contacts she was able to call on to help smooth the way to the Zurich Conference. Do you think he loved her for her understanding of Molière?
He was grooming intelligence assets. That's what he did.
He wasn't interested in having a daughter for its own sake. You can tell that by how he treated the one who wasn't useful to him.
That's not....
It is! And the fact that you didn't know that means you didn't really know him. It's not fair, I know, but....
Je suis désolée. I... have a meeting I need to attend.
You're an oiler in an oiler's job, and that's what matters. What else did they say?
You're not sorry at all.
*VWOM*
Those damn noisemakers just keep getting louder. It's gotta be close, right?
You'd think so.
*VWOM*
Any luck getting the Japanese and the Soviet Pacific Fleet to agree to help us box the thing in the way we did back by Rostock?
I've gotten them to concede that the tactic worked reasonably well over there. It's progress.
*VWOM*
The Soviet admirals want the help. The Japanese seem to think the League wants to trick them into giving up sovereignty.
When in fact the League is openly asking them to give up some sovereignty.
*VWOM*

Fields.MenuText: Be clever *after* we've sunk this thing.
It's not a trivial distinction.
Heh.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm clever all the time, Captain. It's a burden.
The Japanese government might disagree.
Wait - over there.
*VWOM*
I mark destroyers. I don't see anything we can shoot to make the noise stop.
Still worth doing.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Is there a Neutrality Fleet plan for how we're going to handle Christmas?
*VWOM*
This may not be the time.
Capitaine, Morganas attack us constantly and Christmas is four days away. There may not be a better time.
You take your holidays seriously, I see.
Noël will be joyeux if I have to personally strangle a dozen Morganas to make it happen.

Fields.MenuText: I admire your Christmas spirit.
We stockpiled in Rostock. I can't guarantee fresh turkey and ham, but a bunch of the Western sailors got hold of a tree.
Less chatter on the bridge, people. Morganas are close.

Fields.DialogueText: It's what St. Peter Canisius would have wanted.
St. who?
St. Peter Canisius. This is his feast day.
I lived in France. You cannot convince me that that's something every Catholic knows.
Formidable! Now if we can get apples to hang from it from the Japanese...
Pardonnez-moi, Capitaine.
*VWOM*
If a non-Christian might intrude for a moment-
Have we had radio contact?
No. The opposite. The interference is getting more intense.
*VWOM*
Makes sense.
While we're all here - Yeoman Savary, may I respectfully ask what the hell you said to Sayako? She's been shut down for days.
Not a conversation we're having on the bridge, Mr. Cassel.

Fields.MenuText: Though it's a good question.
Miss Kirishima's an adult, anyway. If she wants you to know, she'll tell you.
In fact, we need you back in the radio room. If there's anything to be heard-

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. Yes, sir.
*ALARM*
Never mind. Here we go.
@BATTLE
So that port over there is Hakodate, huh? Seems nice.
It does.
Everything's probably frozen, though.
Could be. I hear they have hot springs here, though...
So... you and Enoch and our Belle and whoever else are talking to some admirals, huh? Trying to bring the Japanese further into the fold. Do you need a translator?
They're bringing their own. I'm thinking of parking you somewhere where you can overhear, though. You have a way of being overlooked when you want to be, and you might pick up something useful.
Way to make a girl feel special, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Hey. It's important.
Rough week, huh?
Would you rather I just stand here quietly?

Fields.DialogueText: Haaiiiii.
No. It's fine.
Please don't.
You've heard there's going to be a party, the night of the twenty-fourth? Morganas permitting.
Marie-France's big to-do. Good for her.
It's not hers. It's for the whole crew - and that very much includes you.
Mochiron. I know.
I know you know. But I want you to believe that it matters.
Matters... You know what matters?
It's only been, like, three months since Bertie died.
A week ago I was feeling guilty because I wasn't sad every minute of every day. Now it's like I don't know if I have the right to feel sad at all.

Fields.MenuText: I don't follow.
Listen - don't waste time wondering if you ought to feel how you feel. Just accept it and try to keep it in perspective.
In situations like that, I usually choose to sink Morganas. Does wonders for my mood.

Fields.DialogueText: That's fine. I don't either, really.
Heh.
I *am* sorry I'm such a hassle, Kanchou.
Kirishima, you know I don't tolerate groundless insults of valued members of my crew.
*ALARM*
Kusoooo.
@BATTLE
The ones full of snow monkeys?
The very same.
I hope we get a chance for some shore leave. But that's not what I ...
What were you going to say, Seaman?
I'm not gonna lie. The extra Japanese support is helpful, but-
But it would be even more helpful if they were friendly with the Soviet Pacific Fleet. I'm working on it.
Does that mean more high-level meetings?

Fields.MenuText: Not if I can possibly avoid them.
Try to contain your excitement, Lieutenant.
Apparently, it's what the League has started paying me for.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds to me like that means more high-level meetings.
I'll do my best, Captain.
Wait. You're getting paid?
Heh. Well-
Sir? Sayako's been helping me out in the radio room-
Is that what we're calling it now?
Ease up, Lieutenant.
It's not a great signal - very faint. But we think we're getting distress calls. Bad Morgana Mist in Uchu... dammit....
Uchiura Bay?
That's it. And we could hear those Morgana drum things in the background.
Hell. Set us a course!
@BATTLE
Here you all are! The party's in the mess, you know.
Nee and nein. The real party is out here.
You see? Vodka. Where the vodka is is the real party. It's an INPF rule.
Is it?
Since we seem to be the ones inventing the INPF rules, I say yes.
Hai!
Ah, vodka. You know, I haven't had any of this stuff since the harpy-
I'm right here, you lomperd.
-since the fine surgeon who also happens to be a harpy used my supply to clean my wounds.
Ja, that was funny.
I hate you so much.
So, Kanchou, Enoch was just telling us all how he ended up going to France in the first place.
I think I'm too sober for that.
No excuses!
But-
Now!
Yes, ma'am.
But it's a stupid story, and you've all heard some version of it a hundred times. I was... three years into my undergrad studies, I guess.
In Haarlem?
It's Harlem, not Haarlem. But, no, Howard. Howard University. But it was summer, and I was home in Harlem helping out in the family store, and one night my cousins and I went out to this jazz club-
It was a speakeasy.
It was *not* a speakeasy. It was a legitimate club that just paid a lot of bribes and had a special menu.
Sounds like my sister's apartment.
... So we were at this club, and-
Was there a *girl*?
Will you let me talk?
There was a girl. There's always a girl.
Unless there's a boy.
Shut up. And, yes, there was a girl. Algerian, but she was from Paris.
Was she pretty?
Like the first full moon in spring.
Awwwww.
Awwwww.

Fields.MenuText: Awwwww.
Let the man talk, people.
Yeah, I'm going back to the real party.

Fields.DialogueText: Et tu, Captain?
Yeah, you asked for this nonsense.
Can I go with you?
Go on, Enoch.
So, you have to imagine, I was wearing my best suit, and I looked like-
*ALARM*
Potselui mou zhopy!
General quarters, people. Party's suspended.
Ugh. God bless us, every one.
@BATTLE
Merry Christmas again, Kanchou. What're you looking at?
I honestly don't know. I mean, it's from the League, but it's not really attributed to anybody, and it's not orders.
Somebody seems to want to know if I think we should investigate the Indian National Congress for possible Morgana collusion.
India has a congress? Poor them.
It's a political party. They're protesting being brought into the war by the British without consultation and-
Which war? Our war? Or the stupid land war?
More the latter than the former. India has a lot of coastline, and I don't think any Indian politician seriously objects to its defense.
So somebody wants us to lean on an Indian political party for not wanting to fight Germans and they're saying it's the Morganas' fault.
A little bit confusingly put, but I think you've got the gist.
Is this British intelligence? Is this something they'd do? Are they... I mean, would they try to use us for something stupid?
Take a breath.
I don't think this is a formal propaganda effort or anything. It's probably just some bored desk jockey sending out strange ideas on official stationery.
Why do you ask?
Argh. I don't know. I'm trying to figure out how furious I am with somebody onboard.

Fields.MenuText: It's good to have a hobby, I guess.
Be furious with the Morganas. We don't have time for anything else.
Is this a problem for the captain?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd rather it were table tennis.
Hai, hai.
No. Thank you, though.
Oh. Um... I told Lugin-san-
Hearing you refer to him so respectfully just... seems wrong.
I know, right?
But he wanted you to know that he's made some friends at Hakodate, and there's this onmyōji who wants to come work for us.
Onmyōji. You mean, a real-
Court astrologer kind of thing? I guess so. I mean, I don't think the Japanese government licenses these guys anymore, but Orest swears he's a legitimate master of the five elements and whatnot.
... I feel like Lugin must have lost a bet somewhere.
So should I say we don't want the guy?

Fields.MenuText: I never say no to fresh crew members.
Well, I'm not going to pull any strings to get him.

Fields.DialogueText: Understood, Kanchou. I'll let him-
*ALARM*
Later!
@BATTLE
Understood, Kanchou. I'll let him-
So we have a plan, Captain?
After days of nonstop insane diplomacy... maybe.
An expanded group of Soviet ships will be helping to contain Morganas, but they'll be flying under the League flag while in Japanese waters.
Which I assume means that the Soviet Union hasn't been kicked out over Finland in the time we've been here.
Correct.
Any chance they're withdrawing from Finland?
My primary source of information here is Soviet political officers, and they're just saying that the USSR is working with the League to expose Morgana involvement in the conflict regions.
Sounds like a no.
But maybe if the League confirms the Finns aren't working with Morganas there'll be room to maneuver. I don't know - we're here and they're there.
And, over here, while the Soviet ships are under the League flag, most of the Japanese ships will be flying Japanese colors but "cooperating fully" with representatives of the League - i.e., us.
And your own national origins...?
Irrelevant for the time being.
And the dispute over those islands in the Kuril chain? Is that settled?
So I think we've all agreed to present a common defense and defer the question of ownership until such time as both parties can shout at each other without Morgana interference.

Fields.MenuText: And without me threatening to relocate to Fiji while they sort things out themselves.
It's been tense, but people are scared enough to listen to reason. To a point, anyway.
It's not great, but I really think it's the best we can get.

Fields.DialogueText: Have we totally ruled that one out?
I'll take it.
Now all we have to do is clear a critical mass of Morganas away from Hokkaido and the Kamchatka Peninsula, secure a Morgana thumper for joint study, and prove that what we're offering is worthwhile.
Almost feels like a vacation.
@BATTLE
Sort of. I get the sense that the Soviets' real worry right now is keeping the League from finding out how bad the situation is at the Strait of Tartary - and I can live with that.
*BOOM*
We're on course to intercept, but I don't know if we're going to be in time to save that destroyer.
Our friendly Belle said she was going to give us more speed, Lieutenant. Assume she's right.
*BOOM*
Since when does Vanity sneak up on people, anyway? She usually might as well have her own fanfare!
We'll figure it out later!
@BATTLE
Capitaine? I have preliminary casualty reports, if you're ready for them.
... Are you all right, Yeoman?
Oui. Oh, the blood isn't mine.
Docteur van Geffen... she needed another pair of hands.
Is it bad down there?
Not so bad as it could have been. What happened? May I ask?
Radios are down again. Hard to tell.
Not that hard. In the Baltic we tried to deal with those Morgana devices by herding them and boxing them in with destroyer groups, leaving us free to close in for the kill.
We tried the same thing here, but the enemy was ready - they came at the main Japanese destroyer group with battleships, from somewhere.
The Soviet fleet may be looking at the same kind of problem. Lieutenant-
Right. We'll lay in a course for their last known coordinates.
No. Figure out the course, but hold off on departure. I don't want to leave these destroyers if they need assistance.
Once our Belle wraps up damage control, somebody get her into the radio room to help Cassel and Kirishima get back in touch with the Japanese group.
I don't think they're in danger of sinking, but a status report would be welcome.
Can't she just talk to their Belles directly?
Maybe. Depends on range and how badly hurt they are.
In the meantime - somebody get word to Mr. Cassel. He's to send out a Russian-language warning for our Soviet friends.
Have him put as much power into it as he can - I want that signal to carry all the way to the Aleutians if we can swing it.
I'll let him know, sir!
Yeoman. You had reports?
Oui. Voilà.
So... was this useful somehow? If you think the Morganas learned from your strategy in the Baltic and communicated it halfway around the world, is that something you can... fix?

Fields.MenuText: I'll get back to you on that.
I've always assumed they had that potential. For all we know, anything one Destruction sees every Destruction sees.
We fix it by blowing them up. That's not new.

Fields.DialogueText: That'll be all. I'll let you know when I'm ready to sign off on these.
Merci, Capitaine.
I know it's asking a lot. I know I'm asking you to risk your ship and your crew for citizens of a nation you've competed with off and on for decades-
Qu'est-ce qui se passe?
The Captain's trying to talk the Japanese captains into helping us rescue the Soviets so the Soviets can help them defend Hokkaido.
SSH!
But the Soviet Union isn't your enemy today.
We're all human. We want our homelands to be strong and safe. We want our families to be healthy and proud. We want the respect of our neighbors and room to achieve what we can achieve.
Sometimes that sets us against each other, but we can always understand it.
That's not true of the Funayūrei. You know it isn't. You've taken fire from them. You've breathed their poison air. Hell, you've heard them.
You know we have to fight them, and we have to do it together. I say this as one officer to another - it's our duty. It's why we're here.
Hai.
Our ships have taken damage, Captain. But... we can keep up with you. As long as it takes.
I never doubted it for a moment, Kanchou. And I'm proud to fight alongside you.
Our kami will send your kami the new course. I mean to leave within the hour.
We'll be ready. *click*
Goodness. Formidable, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Kind of you to say.
We don't have much time, Yeoman. What can I do for you?
I think I was just quoting a speech I gave to some Germans a month ago.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I had to say something, so why not be kind?
I'm sorry to intrude, Capitaine. I just-
At least it was a good one.
Why are you here?
You wanted to review the notes I took from your meeting with the representatives from Nakajima Aircraft, Capitaine.
About getting more scouts, yes. Sorry, it'll have to wait.
So you can go somewhere else now.
Kirishima.
Non. It's fine. I told her something she didn't want to hear. And it-
It's actually more that you told me something that wasn't true.
I know you didn't know him, but everybody else in this room *did* know and like your father. He was funny, and he helped people, and he cared endlessly about everything.
Not everything.
Well, maybe the problem was with you and your mother, because nobody else I know had anything bad to say about the man.
Enough!

Fields.MenuText: Do this on your own time.
Please don't make me give another unity speech.
If you continue to escalate this, I can find room for you both in the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou...
*ALARM*
Oh, thank God.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Give me thirty seconds! Just changing into a clean shirt!
Sorry to bother you, sir! The lady of the ship thought you should know-
*ALARM*
I think I figured it out.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
If you're here to tell me there are more Morganas on the way, do it from the other side of the door so I can't strangle you!
Nice of you to give warning.

Fields.MenuText: If I'd known it was you, I might not've.
Sorry. Long day.
It's the responsibilities of office.

Fields.DialogueText: What can I do for you, Doctor?
Well, I obviously didn't do the traditional house call to the bridge after the last fight. Thought I'd make sure you're not dead.
Have you come to any conclusions?
If you're a corpse, you're an unusually surly-looking one.
Long day. Then a battle. Then taking advantage of clear radio to get Soviet and Japanese captains to publicly admit that we're all on the same side and fight well together.
Somehow that last part took two hours.
But the Soviet destroyers got clear?
They did.
So I guess we've just about won the war, huh?
Heh.
Changing subjects - the kid asked me to tell you she's really sorry for mouthing off at the French girl.

Fields.MenuText: We have an overstressed multinational crew that gets into fist-fights in every port. I can live with some mouthing off.
Tell her she doesn't have to apologize. She just needs to solve the problem.
Yeah, I know she is.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Do you think this is something I can help her with?
You already did. You assigned her to follow me around and bask in my wisdom, remember?
Oh, boy.
I think that's finally them. I think we have visual confirmation of the noise-maker.
*VWOM*
I hope so. I'm really looking forward to shutting that thing up.
@BATTLE
Mr. Cassel, round up the translators and tell our Japanese and Soviet friends where they can find the noise-maker. And gently remind them that I expect them to share access in the agreed-upon manner.
And somebody find Yeoman Savary and tell her that we're going to need her to take notes on a strategic review with me, our Belle, Lieutenant McPhee, and all the regulars in about two hours.
That could've gone worse.

Fields.MenuText: We were lucky finding them when we did. The target could've been hundreds of miles away.
Still a master of understatement, Lieutenant.
Could've gone a whole lot better, too.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm wondering if we need to use destroyers much more aggressively as scouts. Belle senses give us advantages no navy on earth has ever had before.
If we had networks of fast-moving ships out there that could find Morganas and then relay the location along to heavier strike forces....
Isn't air power the way to go there, though?
We've had too many documented instances of Morganas messing with the weather for us to take that for granted.
But that means we need to work on improving Belle-to-Belle communication, or boosting the power of our radio signals, or something. Morganas being able to cut us off at will is getting-
Sir? It sounds like a Russian submarine Belle has gotten into a shouting match with a Japanese destroyer Belle, and the captains are hoping you might be willing to get on the radio and mediate.
Godspeed, Captain. Godspeed.
"Speed" isn't the problem here. What I need is common sense.
Divine or mortal, but we need it yesterday.
I think this is where I left you all on Christmas Eve.
As a good and observant atheist, I feel I should remind you that Christmas is actually in January.
I don't think the tree's going to last that long.
I'm not sure *I'm* going to last that long.
Ja, that's why we're changing your diet.
Don't even joke about it.
So is this the official unofficial New Year's Eve party?
We're just killing time until the alarms sound.
As are we all. Good to see you and the yeoman getting along.
Actually, they're refusing to make eye contact and Sayako keeps grumbling under her breath about needing to go oil some pipes.

Fields.MenuText: Right. Never mind.
I'll take it.
That's what I meant.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen, I've spent more time making speeches in the last three months than I ever wanted to in my entire life. And that's not how I want to spend New Year's Eve.
Here it comes. Marie-France, you're going to want to write this down.
Or maybe we should just record it.
Shut up.
I didn't get the year I was expecting on the first of January, 1939. None of us did.
I know it's easy to look out there and see the end of the world. So much of what we always took for granted has just... fallen away.
And I think we all recognize that it's going to get worse before it gets better.
Great talk.
Hsst!
But the appearance of the Belles tells me that whatever supernatural forces are arrayed against us, we have some on our side as well. And I'm proud to call them friends.
And you idiots.
If any one thing gives me hope for the future, it's that somehow the universe conspired to get you here, where you're desperately needed, just when we needed you.
